journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Frequency determination in control applications: excitation-based approach

contrib-group.aff: Department of Signals and Systems, Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden

author-notes.corresp: Alexander Stotsky, Department of Signals and Systems, Chalmers University of Technology, Gothenburg, SE-412 96, Sweden. Email: alexander.stotsky@chalmers.se

abstract.p: New algorithms for estimation of the frequencies of oscillating waveform signals are described. A model of the signals is presented in the form of a linear difference equation with unknown coefficients, which define the frequencies and amplitudes. Coefficients are estimated utilizing the property of the persistence of excitation of oscillating signals. Exponentially damped and oscillating signals are described in a unified framework. A property of excitation is proved for an exponentially damped signal that contains a single frequency via diagonal dominance of an information matrix. Two applications of this frequency estimation technique are considered. The first one is filtering of the wind speed signal in wind turbine control applications, and the second one is the frequency estimation of exponentially damped signals motivated by the engine knock detection applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Oscillating waveform signals appear in a large number of applications, including active noise, vibration and rotating machinery control, radar/sonar, seismic, audio, and biomedical signal processing, and many others. Estimation of unknown frequencies (frequency contents) of oscillating signals is an important problem of digital signal processing, which has been addressed in many articles.

A discrete-time adaptive estimation algorithm for a multifrequency signal based on the gradient update law and notch filter was proposed by Regalia.1 A convergence analysis was performed using the associated differential equation,2,3 which proves the local stability of the system. This article was the basis for a globally convergent continuous-time frequency estimator of a single frequency, based on classical adaptive control methods.4 Continuous-time version of the algorithm proposed by Regalia1 is also described in Bodson and Douglas.5 Recent algorithms of identification of a single frequency are based on the internal model principle,6 where the model is transformed and linearized with respect to unknown frequency.7–10 The method is well discussed for both continuous- and discrete-time cases as well as for exponentially damped signals (EDSs).11,12

Many, if not all, oscillating signals are sufficiently rich (persistently exciting). Therefore, one of the most promising approaches to frequency estimation in real-time applications is adaptive estimation techniques, where the parameter convergence is guaranteed by the persistence of excitation. This often simplifies an estimator and makes it very attractive for real-time applications. An excitation-based adaptive technique for estimation of a continuous-time multifrequency signal was proposed in Marino and Tomei13 and extended further in Xia14 and Hou.15

Discrete-time estimation of multifrequency signals is considered in this article in a unified framework for both oscillating and EDSs. The properties of an information matrix (such as strict diagonal dominance (SDD)) are the main focus of this article. These properties are important for both algorithm design and stability analysis and might be used in different ways depending on a model of the signal, which, in turn, is application oriented.

Two models of the oscillating signals are considered in this article. The first one is specified in the form of trigonometric polynomial (a sum of sines and cosines of known frequencies) with unknown coefficients. This model is well suited for frequency domain system identification, where the frequency response of dynamical system is analyzed via estimation of the parameters,16,17 and the convergence of these parameters is guaranteed by the persistence of excitation.18 The regressor vector consists of trigonometric functions (sines and cosines) at different frequencies in this case, and the corresponding information matrix is an SDD matrix (a matrix is said to be an SDD matrix if in every row of the matrix, the magnitude of the diagonal entry in that row is larger than the sum of the magnitudes of all the other (nondiagonal) entries in that row19) that allows application of new fast convergent algorithms for parameter estimation.20

The second model that describes the oscillating signal is a linear difference equation with unknown coefficients to be estimated. All the roots of the corresponding characteristic polynomial of this equation are complex and divided into conjugate pairs, where each pair defines the frequency and amplitude at this frequency. A regressor vector consists of the past values of the output in this case, and also a persistently exciting due to the oscillating properties of the signal.13 The two models described above are related via the solution of the difference equation, which contains trigonometric functions. However, the properties of information matrices based on different regressor vectors are also different for these two models. It is proved in this article that the information matrix of the second model is an SDD matrix for single-frequency signals, and the properties of this matrix should be further studied for the case of multifrequency signals.

Two new applications of the frequency estimation technique based on the persistence of excitation are described in this article in a unified framework. The first one is related to the reduction of the wind speed model in wind turbine control applications, and the second one is the frequency estimation of EDS motivated by the engine knock detection applications.

The article is organized as follows. Excitation-based parameter estimation technique is described in the next section followed by a new filtering technique of the wind speed signal in the wind turbine application and frequency estimation of EDS in sections “Wind speed model reduction: excitation-based filtering” and “Frequency determination of EDS,” respectively. The article ends with some discussions in section “Discussion.”

This matrix is not an SDD matrix for multifrequency signals, and therefore, fast and computationally efficient algorithms mentioned above cannot be applied for parameter estimation in this case. Properties of this matrix should be further studied that might lead to the performance improvement of the excitation-based estimation algorithms.

Many algorithms can be applied for estimation of the parameter vector
θ
*

θ
k
to
θ
*
is guaranteed by excitation (10). One such algorithm is the simple Kaczmarz algorithm where the output of the model matches the measured signal exactly in each discrete step and the vector of the parameter mismatch is orthogonal to the regressor vector. Computational simplicity and robustness against measurement noise make Kaczmarz algorithm very attractive for estimation of the frequency contents of complex signals with a large number of frequencies in real-time applications. A parameter convergence is guaranteed by the property of the persistence of excitation (10). The roots of polynomial (2) can be calculated as soon as its coefficients are identified and the frequencies of the signal can then be calculated.

Kaczmarz algorithms are summarized in Table 1. The classical Kaczmarz algorithm modified with the gain matrix
Γ
k
is shown in the first row of Table 1. Three items are listed for the gain update algorithms. The first item, where the gain matrix is equal to identity matrix, corresponds to a classical Kaczmarz algorithm,21 and the second and third ones describe Kaczmarz algorithms modified with least-squares gain updates.20,22,23 The third item shows the least-squares gain update with a forgetting factor, and the forgetting factor of the second one is equal to one.
These algorithms are applied to the frequency determination in the following sections.

sec.title: Wind speed model reduction: excitation-based filtering
sec.p: Future laser sensor technologies will be capable of measuring wind speed at a distance in front of the wind turbine with relatively high sample rates.24 Wind speed signal measured at a distance in front of the turbine allows preprocessing and generation of a high-quality feedforward control signal.25 A time series model in the form of equation (1) is widely used for prediction of wind speed oscillations at a distance in front of the wind turbine (see for example Kusiak et al.26 and Sirdas27 and references therein). A low-frequency component should be extracted from the noise-contaminated wind speed measurements in front of the turbine to achieve a high-performance turbine regulation. A low-pass filtering, which the simplest solution in this case, introduces a phase lag and might have a negative impact on the power efficiency of the turbine. Excitation-based filtering of the wind speed signal, described in this article, provides a computationally efficient solution without a phase lag. It is assumed that the wind speed is described by linear difference equation (1) with unknown coefficients. Wind speed model is specified in the form of equation (9) with the parameters adapted via Kaczmarz algorithm

where a gain matrix
Γ
k
is adjusted via the second algorithm in Table 1. As soon as the coefficients of polynomial (2) are found, its complex roots are calculated. These roots define the frequencies and amplitudes at each frequency. Filtering of the wind speed signal is performed via a selection of the lowest frequency. As soon as the low-frequency component of the wind speed signal is extracted, its derivative, which is taken analytically, can be used in the feedforward part of the turbine speed controller.25
This filtering approach is illustrated in Figure 1, which shows the wind speed signal that contains three frequencies filtered via excitation-based filtering.

caption.p: Filtering of the wind speed signal that contains three frequencies. Frequencies are identified using the approach described in section ‘Wind speed model reduction: excitation-based filtering.’ The lowest frequency is selected for the filtered signal.

sec.title: Frequency determination of EDS
sec.p: Determination of the frequencies of the EDS is motivated by the engine signal–processing applications.28 A knock detection circuit that is based on the signal of an accelerometer installed on the engine block of a spark ignition automotive engine has a band-pass filter with a certain frequency as a parameter to be calibrated. A determination of the frequency, which is the most suitable for the knock detection, is very important for real-time applications. In the case of knocking, an accelerometer reads exponentially vanishing oscillating signals. Similar signals also appear in seismic and audio signal–processing applications. Notice that EDSs are excited over some finite intervals only, and sufficient intensity is required for frequency estimation.

Frequency estimation of a single-frequency EDS is plotted in Figure 2, and the frequency estimation of the signal that contains three frequencies, which is shown in Figure 3, is plotted in Figure 4.

caption.p: Frequency estimation of an EDS that contains a single frequency using the second algorithm given in Table 1, described in section “Frequency estimation: excitation-based approach.”
Frequency estimation of the signal plotted in Figure 3 using the third algorithm in Table 1, described in section “Frequency estimation: excitation-based approach.”

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Richness of the oscillating signals can successfully be used for frequency estimation. These signals are modeled using linear difference equations with unknown coefficients, which define the frequencies and amplitudes. The convergence of estimated coefficients to their true values is guaranteed by the persistence of excitation that also simplifies estimation algorithms. SDD of the information matrix together with the property of persistence of excitation might successfully be used for the performance improvement of existing estimation algorithms. It is shown that the information matrix (in the case of frequency estimation) is an SDD matrix for single-frequency signals only. Information matrix is not an SDD matrix in the case where the number of frequencies is greater than or equal to 2. The properties of this information matrix and gain matrix
Γ
k
with different forgetting factors (see Table 1) should be further studied for multifrequency signals, aiming at the performance improvement of the excitation-based estimation algorithms.

Besides, frequency determination using this technique requires very high accuracy of estimation of the coefficients of the difference equations. Such an accuracy cannot be achieved in the presence of unmodeled frequencies and significant measurement noise. Therefore, this estimation technique should be applied together with the preprocessing methods that can clean up the signal sufficiently. On the contrary, the coefficients of the trigonometric polynomials with known frequencies in frequency domain identification can be estimated with acceptable accuracy in the presence of significant measurement noise and unmodeled frequencies.
